page.title: 09The Dairy Industry
page.content: The other problem concerns dairy farming. Since Britain is now in the Common Market, farmers have to obey laws which are made by the European Parliament. The Parliament noted that too much milk was being produced, more milk than people were buying. This meant that many dairy farmers had to cut the size of their herds. In other words valuable cows had to be killed. A farmer who spent years breeding a fine herd of cattle would be very upset if ordered to destroy some of his animals. As the West country is a leading milk producing region the farmers around Newton-St-Loe were affected by the new law in 1985. Animals had to be sold or killed if the herd size was above the official "quota".
